resources.string: Cowntdown

Cowntdown was created to keep the \"wake-up\" trend alive and make countdowns more engaging. Built using Jetpack Compose and following Clean Architecture, the app ensures a smooth user experience while maintaining scalability.
Worker Notifications – Sends reminders even when the app is closed.
Intuitive Navigation – Simplified user flow using Navigation Compose.
Modern UI – Designed with Material 3, featuring a customizable theme.
Cows have best friends and get stressed when separated from them.
Cows can recognize faces and remember them for years.
A cow\'s moo can be heard up to 6 miles away on a clear day.
Cows have 32 teeth, but they don\'t have upper front teeth.
Cows sleep standing up but lie down to rest deeply.
A cow\'s stomach has four compartments to help digest food.
Cows spend about 8 hours a day eating.
Cows can walk up to 5 miles per hour when they are motivated.
Cows are herbivores, meaning they only eat plants.
The average cow produces about 6.3 gallons of milk every day.
Cows can be as intelligent as dogs, and some can even learn to fetch things.
A cow can weigh between 1,000 to 1,800 pounds on average.
Cows can live up to 20 years or more with proper care.
Cows communicate with each other using a variety of vocalizations, body language, and facial expressions.
A cow\'s sense of smell is 10 times stronger than a human\'s.
Cows can be trained to use a leash like dogs.
In Hinduism, cows are considered sacred animals.
Cows have panoramic vision and can see 360 degrees around them.
Cows spend 50% of their day chewing cud, which is partially digested food that they regurgitate.
Cows have a keen sense of direction and can find their way home from miles away.
Cows\' milk is used to make more than just dairy products—it\'s also used in soaps and lotions.
Cows are social animals and enjoy the company of other cows.
There are over 900 different breeds of cows in the world.
Cows produce methane, a potent greenhouse gas, from digestion, which contributes to global warming.
The longest recorded lifespan of a cow was 48 years.
A cow\'s tongue is so strong it can curl around grass and pull it into its mouth.
Cows are sensitive to sound and will often respond to certain music.
Cows are known to have a great memory, able to remember faces and places for years.
The average cow produces 2.5 times its body weight in milk every year.
The world record for the largest milk-producing cow is 74.5 pounds of milk per day.
Cows can see color, but their vision is different from humans; they see shades of red and blue better than other colors.
Cows are ruminants, meaning they regurgitate food from their stomach to chew it again.
A cow\'s udders can hold up to 25 liters of milk at a time.
Cows\' hooves are tough and can support the weight of the animal without any problems.
Cows have been domesticated for over 10,000 years.
The average cow can produce around 350,000 glasses of milk in its lifetime.
Cows like to be brushed, and some can be trained to enjoy a good back scratch.
The tallest cow ever recorded stood at 6 feet 4 inches tall.
Cows are gentle animals that tend to form deep bonds with each other.
Cows\' milk contains about 87% water, which helps keep them hydrated.
A group of cows is called a herd.
Cows are excellent swimmers and can even swim across rivers if needed.
Cows have a very strong sense of hearing, and they can hear frequencies up to 23,000 Hz.
Cows are herbivores and mainly graze on grass, but they also eat other plants like clover and hay.
Cows can walk in a straight line, but if you try to confuse them, they will start walking in circles.
Cows can give birth to twins, although it is rare.
Cows are used to help maintain ecosystems by grazing on vegetation, which helps prevent wildfires.
Cows have been shown to be able to solve simple puzzles when motivated with food.
Cows\' eyes are located on the sides of their heads, which allows them to see predators from a distance.
Cows can walk up to 2 miles per hour when they are calm.
Cows have a very good sense of smell, and they can detect odors from up to 5 miles away.
Cows are often depicted as lazy, but they can be quite active, especially when they are playing or interacting with other cows.
Cows can form strong emotional bonds with humans and can recognize their caretakers.
The average dairy cow weighs around 1,200 pounds (545 kg).
Cows are often trained to respond to their names and can recognize the voice of their owner.
The milk produced by cows contains over 200 different components, including vitamins, minerals, proteins, and fat.
Cows communicate with their owners using body language and vocalizations, just like other animals.
The heaviest cow ever recorded weighed 3,000 pounds (1,360 kg).
Cows are often seen as a symbol of fertility and abundance in many cultures.
A cow\'s stomach has four compartments: the rumen, reticulum, omasum, and abomasum.
Cows have a large, sensitive nose that helps them find food, water, and even detect danger.
Cows are sometimes given names based on their personalities or markings.
Cows can express a wide range of emotions, from happiness and contentment to frustration and fear.
Cows are one of the most important sources of food for humans, providing milk, cheese, butter, and meat.
Cows are very social creatures and can develop deep friendships with other cows.
Cows have a very strong maternal instinct and will fiercely protect their calves.
Cows are often used in therapy programs because of their calm and peaceful nature.
The fastest cow can run up to 20 miles per hour (32 km/h).
Cows produce milk for a full year after giving birth, even if they are not continuously pregnant.
Cows are creatures of habit and prefer to follow a consistent routine.
The average cow produces about 150,000 glasses of milk over its lifetime.
Cows have been domesticated for thousands of years, providing essential resources for human civilization.
Cows are capable of walking over 6 miles (10 km) a day in search of food.
Cows\' milk is rich in calcium, which is important for bone health.
Cows love to be outside in the sunshine and will often seek shade when it gets too hot.
Some cows can be trained to pull carts or wagons, similar to horses.
Cows\' eyes have an excellent range of vision, allowing them to see in almost all directions at once.
Cows can produce milk with different fat content, ranging from low-fat to full-fat milk.
Cows have an amazing sense of balance and can even stand on uneven terrain.
Cows can be trained to walk on a leash like dogs and even go on walks with their owners.
Cows\' milk is used to create a wide range of dairy products, including cheese, butter, and yogurt.
Cows are sometimes used to help graze and control unwanted vegetation in areas such as parks or golf courses.
Cows love to be brushed and enjoy being pampered by their caretakers.
Some cows have unique coat patterns, with patches of different colors and shapes.
Cows are capable of forming complex relationships with other animals, including humans, dogs, and even cats.
